prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Venus Atmospheric Structure and Circulation: Morning Terminator
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Whole disk mapping of 12CO,13CO spectral line absorptions in the Venus extended (70-120 km altitude) atmosphere samples full latitudinal and *AM* local times, including the morning terminator, to support global temperature, CO, and Doppler wind profile retrievals. These unique profile mapping measurements place critical constraints on circulation and transport in the diurnal (subsolar-to-antisolar) flow regime of the upper Venus atmosphere, including key definition and distinction of the morning terminator cross-terminator supersonic flow regime to companion cycle 2 evening terminator observations (in Mar-Apr 2015).

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: Date range is required for observation of the targeted Venus phase (corresponding to range of Venus local time visible from Earth, which includes the morning terminator).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Time Constraints: Observation IS TIME CONSTRAINED as it must be conducted within Jun1-30, 2014. The OT time constrained box is set to NO only because an OT would otherwise generate an (incorrect) error. The time range corresponds to science requirements for (1) Venus phase (0.75-0.85), and (2) Imaging across AM (not PM) terminator. Jun1-30, 2014 also corresponds to Venus disk size small enough to satisfy ALMA maximum spatial scale constraints (see below).
Our science requires Venus phase 0.75-0.85 in order to both: (1) Observe a Venus local time range that includes sufficient fractions of both day and nightside to adequately map the cross-terminator day/night transition, and (2) Map Venus when the terminator is closer to the limb than to the sub-Earth meridian. This optimizes sensitivity to cross-terminator winds, as the horizontal winds present a larger doppler (vs proper motion) component.
Maximum Spatial Scale: Jun1-30, 2014 corresponds to Venus diameter 12"-14". We therefore require both 12-m and ACA observations, for spatial scale recovery up to 12". For the special case of planets, observations of disk size up to 15" is justified as follows (Butler & Bastion, 1999): Data analysis will include modeling a priori knowledge of large scale planetary brightness (eg. limb darkened uniform brightness disk). This, together with the nominal 12" 12-m/ACA maximum scale enables understanding of spatial variation up to 15''. Team members Sagawa, Gurwell, Butler, and Moullet have extensive experience in the required modeling.
Backend: CO 3-2 observations require Band-7. Dual polarization observations (of these unpolarized absorptions) provide best sensitivity. Frequency resolution for all objectives must be better than 200 KHz (line thermal width) for optimal retrieval of wind, and of temperature, CO profiles above ~100 km. The very broad (symmetric) 12CO absorption requires a 2nd, wider spectral window for T/CO retrieval below ~80 km. Our 938 (+/-469) MHz window, centered 250 MHz below 12CO line meets the requirement with measurements to 720 MHz negative (and 220 MHz positive) offset.
Note that 200 kHz resolution yields doppler wind precisions of +/-10 m/s (~10 kHz) (Fig 4; also Clancy et al, 2012a). Wind speed precision exceeding spectral velocity resolution is retrieved based upon use of many channels (slope of absorption vs freq). Venus strong 12CO absorption (60% at line center, 30% at +/-1 MHz offset, Fig 4) is optimal for high precision wind retrieval.
Simultaneous 12CO & 13CO spectra are required for retrieval of both temperature and CO profiles. With only one absorption (12CO or 13CO), the system is underdetermined, such that neither temperature nor CO can be usefully retrieved. Three spectral windows are required, two for 12CO (see above), and one for 13CO. ACA and 12-m observations may be scheduled independently within the Jun1-30, 2014 window. They do *NOT* need to be simultaneous. See Science Justification for details.
Required Spatial Resolution and Sensitivity: 0.45'' spatial resolution is required to map the day-to-night cross-terminator transition with sufficient resolution to map local time variation within the narrow nightside crescent as well as across the terminator. At the targeted phase, 0.45'' resolution provides this for latitudes 50S-50N (4-8 pixels at equator; 3-5 pixels at 50S, 50N).
Based upon our experiences with 12CO, 13CO Venus spectra from the JCMT, measurement sensitivity of 0.65 K for 13CO is required for accurate retrieval of Doppler wind altitude profiles, our most demanding objective, and is more than adequate for temperature, CO profile retrievals.
OT-estimated Time Requirement: The OT estimates that 3.91 hours (total, including 12-m, ACA, and overhead) for each time period (each Science Goal). Total time for the project would thus be 7.82 hours.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Venus above-cloud (>70km) atmosphere exhibits complex photochemistry (S, C, Cl, H, N, O-compounds), diurnally forced circulation, and extreme global variability, none of which is adequately understood or observationally defined. The distinct day vs night circulations may be forced by asymmetric supersonic flow across the AM vs PM terminators (effectively a global airfall). Our specific objective is to characterize dynamical, thermal, and compositional gradients (in local-time and latitude) across both AM (June1 - 30, 2014) and PM (Mar.1 - Apr.15, 2015) terminators (dates for phase ~0.8 & disk size). Simultaneous 12CO, 13CO Band 7 maps support vertical profile (75 - 115 km) temperature, CO, and Doppler wind retrievals, providing 1st-time synoptic definitions of these interdependent fields over the Venus dayside and terminator regions. Sensitivity required for each time period (Science Goal) is 3.91 hr integrations (7.82 hr total). Three spectral windows target the broadband 12CO (938 MHz), and high resolution (<200 KHz) 12CO, 13CO line absorptions. These ALMA observations would provide critical resolution of dynamics and transport in a remarkably distinct atmospheric regime.
